posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Flemish and Walloons don't hate each others
The Flemish movement before WWI was a class/ideological movement (catholic, rural dialect-speaking Flemish versus urban Bourgeois upper-class french-speaking "Belgian", both FL and WAL). Flanders and Wallonia didn't exist as political entities. Belgium was always a conservative, anti-enlightenment country.
When Germany invaded and occupied Belgium in WWI, they imposed a divide and conquer tactics called the "Flamenpolitik".
Basically they divided the country in half and told one half that the other half stole their waffles.
This is something the flemish don't like to hear but the impact of the flamenpolitik is huge to this day.

The economic situation inverted in the 70's. Antwerp port profited from globalism and Walloon manufacture outsourced and flemish nationalism turned into a bourgeois nationalism after the 2000s (actually not different from the francophone bourgeoisie of the 19th century).
The Walloon movement on the other hand deplore the disparition of the walloon language, the lack of respect for the region, their discrimination; actually very much similar to the original Flemish movement of the 19th century.

The explanation is here.

https://www.isegoria.net/2014/07/iq-shredders/

The concept, basically, is that places like Hong Kong and Singapore (Japan could be included as well) are very attractive places to live in to a lot of rich expats, but they have very strict immigration policies, that screen for only the most talented people. Living in these societies, which have a strict capitalistic work ethic, are very urban and have high rent prices, in turn, discourages people from having kids. So the idea is that they are "IQ shredders", they attract some of the most qualified immigrants from around the world and then discourage them from breeding.

It points to a broader issue of how many developed nations are experiencing below replacement rates which will become a new social issue in the future. (Which as I pointed out CAN'T be solved with le hecking robots, it isn't so simple)

Let's forget political issues, complexity and so on - imagine we're the absolute rulers of the world, let's say we force people with proportionately long torsos, large wrists etc.(highly heritable proxies for height - the nutritional gains seem to be the most visible in limb length) to have more children. Taleb isn't necessarily wrong mind you, his point is something I to some extent agree on, but he doesn't contradict Dawkins on his point. If you'd select some particular traits you'd like, figure out the proxies that allow to estimate their genotypic value(molecular genetics is counting trees in the forest one by one, too sci-fi for this purpose), you could pull off increase or decrease in these particular traits. That in practice the political dimension of this will wreck any attempt at carrying it out and in certain ways you're playing with fire here and can get results you don't want is another thing. For the example of the latter Sweden is great. Swedes had long lasting eugenic programme until the 1970s or whatever, it was mostly about encouraging convicts to sterilise themselves. A lot of the issues people have with Swedes however is the result of it. Their absolutely insufferable character is in some part the result of it, as is the childish approach to politics etc. The modern criminal was a person bred from people who in the past made fame of themselves by stealing cows from neighbouring village, yes they're violent, rough and sometimes tribalistic to a fault, but they also induces moderation to the risk averse no touchy touchy smug autism of the more orderly part of the society. posts.com:
I attempted praying to Mary and I would like to report my experience and thoughts on the matter, as it may be useful to someone. Recently I came around on some of the Marian dogmas and I thought that it might be beneficial to attempt praying to her, as this is such an important element of piety among Catholics and Orthodox. As a Protestant, when asking Christ for something, I will pray to him and make my request, then if it is not granted, I accept it, knowing that Christ knows what is best and that God wills things for my good. I don't generally make trivial requests, or ask for things like money -- normally I pray for strength regarding sinful temptations. But I had a pressing need regarding a the physical health of a family member, so I prayed to Christ asking that he would help them, and I prayed to Mary, and asked that she would also pray for this family member and ask Christ to help them. I did this on a number of occasions.

Suffice it to say that the prayer has not been answered in any observable way. That is acceptable, of course. I'm not evaluating this as some kind of experiment on whether my prayers will become more effective or something, but I wanted to see how this would affect my spirituality, or how I understand prayer. And I have to say that the change was strong, but in a wholly negative manner. Whereas in the past, I could make my petition, then accept Christ's will and move on, with the involvement of prayers to the saints this changes as there are now more possibilities. It could be that Christ will not grant the petition if I ask it, but he will grant it if Mary asks it ("the prayer of a righteous man avails much"). And perhaps Mary declined my request for prayer. In this case the way to get my prayer granted would be to supplicate Mary so that she might pray as I have requested.

(1/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Do you see the problem? Prayer becomes alienated from Christ and the acceptance of God's will, and becomes attuned to supplicating other humans, or creating the right conditions for your prayer to be accepted. This ties in with other concepts, like needing to pray in particular places, or pray in contact with or near the relics of saints, to increase the efficacy of prayer. It's almost like prayer ends up being more like constructing a spell, and it turns into a superstitious practice. Christ won't answer my prayer, but perhaps if I venerate Mary in my prayers enough, she will help me. Or perhaps if I pray near the bones of so-and-so he will pray for me and it will be sufficient. After all, we need the righteous to pray for us so that God will hear us. Simply asking him ourselves is not sufficient if we need something from Christ. That is the logic that comes to bear. It was at this point that I realized the importance of the Reformers fighting against this practice, and why they understood it as idolatry. Because it points us away from Christ and to other beings, to supplicate them instead of God.

(2/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
But the objection will be: what of James 5:16? Does not the prayer of the righteous have greater efficacy? Should we not seek out the righteous or (in Mary's case) the most righteous to pray for us? This verse gave me some consternation after my experience, but I eventually came to understand what it actually means. The verse in full:
>Confess your trespasses to one another, and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The effective, fervent prayer of a righteous man avails much.
Now the context is that he is telling the readers of the letter to pray for one another. So the prayers he is referring to are the ones performed by the readers of the letter. So who is the "righteous" whose prayers are so effective? Frankly, it is you. Or it is supposed to be you. If you are not righteous you need to demonstrate your faith through your works, as James tells us earlier in the letter. Rather than telling us to seek out the righteous to pray for us, he is telling us to pray for others, because our prayers can help them. The emphasis placed on this verse by Catholics and Orthodox is inverted from its meaning. James wants us to direct our prayers to the benefit of others, the Catholic and Orthodox reading is for us to seek out the prayers of others who are more righteous in order for our own prayers to be answered. See the difference? This is the meaning of Christians praying for each other, not that we seek out particular righteous people to pray for us in a superstitious way, because otherwise Christ may not hear us; but that we love each other and pray for each other, because we wish God to be merciful on all of us. If we love our brother in Christ, we ask God to bless him. To dig beyond this, to try to extrapolate this into a system of efficacy, is to torture the text and miss its entire point.

I repented of my prayers to Mary and I hope others who do this will repent as well.

(3/3)

>>14446443
Darwinian Evolution disproved Lamarckian evolution through a crazy amount of evidence.

Lamarck was wrong; however, in the past few decades, now that we have a bigger understading of Epigenetics, we know that there are some modifications of the *expression* of a genome (through adding uracil, mathyl groups, etc to nucleic acids) CAN be passed from parent to child. like how crack babies are born with unfixable modifications to their genomic expression.
Another example is how mothers who grew up in famine will have babies that express greater fat-retention genes. this is what's happened in india.

So Lamarck was "technically" right in some way. healthy parents will produce healthier children. but don't expect to get abs doing nothing just because your dad did a bunch of crunches.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
http://www.artandpopularculture.com/Cult_of_ugliness

Cult of ugliness refers to a relatively new phenomenon – largely coinciding with the arrival of modern art – in the history of art and aesthetics: the rejection of classical beauty ideals and the embracing of ugliness.

A predecessor for the cult of ugliness was Francis Bacon who said "There is no excellent beauty, that hath not some strangeness in the proportion," not calling the ugly beautiful just yet but "strangeness in proportion" beautiful.

The Romantics where the first to profess a true cult of ugliness with the anonymous dictum "Only the ugly is beautiful, only the ugly is likeable" and Victor Hugo saying "the beautiful has but one type; the ugly has a thousand."

Baudelaire picked up on both Bacon and Hugo and said "what is beautiful is always bizarre".

Naturalistic works of literature such as those of Émile Zola often include uncouth or sordid subject matter. They exposed the dark, harshness of life, including poverty, racism, prejudice, disease, prostitution and filth. These 'warts and all' novels were often criticized for being too blunt.

In his 1913 essay The Serious Artist, Ezra Pound discusses two types of art; The "cult of beauty" and the "cult of ugliness". He compares the former with medical cure and the latter with medical diagnosis, and goes on to write "Villon, Baudelaire, Corbière, Beardsley are diagnosis."

"If - in the 20th century - beauty was exiled from the arts, it found refuge in advertising, fashion, cinema, product design and consumer culture" --Sholem Stein

Marriage fulfils three functions. Social, Religious, and Political/Economic. The religious aspect should be outside the realm of government - and if a church wants to preform a ceremony for gay couples then that's a matter for that church's leadership and congregation. The social aspect is to announce to your friends and family that you think that this relationship is the one you want to keep from now on (although given divorce stats there's some debate about how much this applies now), but again that's not something that you need a government's or church's permission for, just throw a party and announce it. The reason that marriage has legislation around it is for the last one there, the economic factor. A stable, loving, supportive heterosexual family has been proven time and time again to be the best scenario to breed and produce children (the next generation of citizens and workers, hence the government's interest in it). There isn't sufficient data to tell us how gay parents will compare to that just yet - and for such a polarising issue it is almost impossible for a fair and honest study to be conducted/published - but let's be real and acknowledge that at its best it can only be as good as a functional heterosexual marriage, just without the ability to actually breed their own children.

As such it is, in the absolute best possible case, a second rate set up for fulfilling the task of a marriage (from the perspective of the government, the people you are arguing should be involved). >>14445782
Again, this is too reductive. The Dutch definitely saw Chinese as more refined and clever, but this didn't always translate into feelings of warmth or closeness.

Some Dutchmen married women of both races, and there was friendly trade and social intercourse with both, but there were reasons for the Dutch to favour the natives over the Chinese, chief among these was the relative lack of opposition to converting to Christianity and learning Dutch on the part of the natives compared to the Chinese, who were perceived as more haughty and prideful, whether or not this was a fair judgement.

In some ways, the sometimes poor relations between the Dutch and the Chinese was more the fault of the former. The Dutch didn't hesitate to remind the Chinese that they were foreigners like themselves, and as non-natives were, in the Dutch estimation, enjoying the privilege of living and working on Dutch land. They taxed the Chinese heavily and imposed more restrictions on them than the natives, which they Chinese came to resent.

>Is there a logical explanation for why so many explicit true believers in European supremacy had this soft spot for East Asians?

Game recognized game.
While Europeans considered them "behind"; they didn't feel they were an inherently backward or overtly stupid and inferior like the other foreign peoples they had encountered. The splendor, sophistication, and achievements of Chinese and Japanese urban civilization were impressive for their means and displayed a commendable level of culture that even some of the more racist & hardhearted European couldn't deny.

To be more specific, because lots of cultures have dragged stones and built impressive structures, what the Europeans thought was so valid in South East Asia was the presence of "High Culture". Literature, theater, philosophy, paint & sculpture, bureaucracy, public hygiene, minted currencies and markets, and the presence of something resembling formal religious institutions not "too" dissimilar from Christianity.

I was with you up to here: but the perceived alienness of Northeast Asian religion and their reluctance or even violent opposition towards Christianity was a very big stumbling-block in relations between the European powers on one hand, and China, Korea and Japan on the other. >On 6 March, The 1/24th was re-manned and did well, moving over difficult terrain against an entrenched enemy. While climbing up steep terrain, however, the 1/24th reportedly collapsed under Chinese fire and withdrew in disorder. When the Division commander learned of that action, his confidence in the 24th plummeted. Many soldiers of the 24th ran away from the fighting, tossing their weapons and equipment aside. A derisive poem throughout the U.S. Army stated: 'When the Chinaman's mortars begins to thud, the Deuce-Four Niggers begin to bug.'
>Although the 24th performed well in the attack north of the Han and the subsequent general withdrawal of the Eighth Army after the Chinese Spring Offensive of 1951, its reputation was somewhat tarnished. But it performed well in the Army's drive back north in May and June 1951. In September 1950, the 24th's division commander, Gen. William B. The formula of Pope Hormisdas settled the first schism between East and West in AD 519:

>The first condition of salvation is to keep the norm of the true faith and in no way to deviate from the established doctrine of the Fathers. For it is impossible that the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, who said, "Thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my Church," should not be verified. >And so I hope I may deserve to be associated with you in the one communion which the Apostolic See proclaims, in which the whole, true, and perfect security of the Christian religion resides. I promise that from now on those who are separated from the communion of the Catholic Church, that is, who are not in agreement with the Apostolic See, will not have their names read during the sacred mysteries. But if I attempt even the least deviation from my profession, I admit that, according to my own declaration, I am an accomplice to those whom I have condemned. I have signed this, my profession, with my own hand, and I have directed it to you, Hormisdas, the holy and venerable pope of Rome.

The Formula of Hormisdas, which the Eastern bishops signed, sets out the sum and substance of the papal claim as stated in Vatican I.

>>14447765
The Sanskrit word ā́rya (आर्य) was originally an ethnocultural term designating those who spoke Vedic Sanskrit and adhered to Vedic cultural norms (including religious rituals and poetry), in contrast to an outsider, or an-ā́rya ('non-Arya'). By the time of the Buddha (5th–4th century BCE), it took the meaning of 'noble'. In Old Iranian languages, the Avestan term airya (Old Persian ariya) was likewise used as an ethnocultural self-designation by ancient Iranian peoples, in contrast to an an-airya ('non-Arya'). It designated those who belonged to the 'Aryan' (Iranian) ethnic stock, spoke the language and followed the religion of the 'Aryas'.

These two terms derive from the reconstructed Proto-Indo-Iranian stem *arya- or *āryo-, which was probably the name used by the prehistoric Indo-Iranian peoples to designate themselves as an ethnocultural group. The term did not have any racial connotation, which only emerged later in the works of 19th-century Western writers. According to David W. Anthony, "the Rigveda and Avesta agreed that the essence of their shared parental Indo-Iranian identity was linguistic and ritual, not racial. If a person sacrificed to the right gods in the right way using the correct forms of the traditional hymns and poems, that person was an Aryan."

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14446994
Theravada's Pali Canon is basically Vinaya (Monk rules), Suttas (sayings of Buddha) and Abhidhamma. Plus various commentaries tradition.

Vajrayana's Canon is basically Kangyur (basically Viyana/Older suttas/Sarvastivadan Abhidhammas + Mahayana only suttas + tantra suttas) + Tengyur (new tibetan only additions) + commentaries

Chinese Buddhism also has their own Vinaya/Suttas/Sarvastivadan Abhidhamma + Mahanaya suttas + tantra suttas + chinese commentaries.

>To add to the question? I'm just curious at this point, did hinduism supplant buddhism in mainland india but not in sri lanka, which at the time was penninula.
Buddhist support was eroding in mainland India due to various reasons (Huns/loss of monarch support/monastic religion/Islamic raids/etc). Buddhism was an expensive project and without the support of monarchs, it could not sustains itself.
Hinduism was the religion of the common people. Easy to remember suttas through songs/writings. Vs monastic lingos that were alien to most people.

Sri Lanka survived due to relative isolation from mainland chaos, but were still connected to Bengal (buddhist for the longest in India due to Pala dynasty), Burma, Thailand, etc.

Western philosophy is rooted in reason. Its thinkers attempt to build up logical explanations to answer major philosophical questions, which range from the metaphysical and epistemological to the ethical and moral.

Eastern philosophy is rooted in mysticism and tradition. The more ancient a source of wisdom is, the more authoritative it is. Eastern thinkers might use logic to explain their conclusions, or they might not. There's no onus on them to do so, most of the expectation for comprehension is on their disciples. If they can't comprehend the wise master's teachings, it is because they are not enlightened enough.

>>14432409
From these pre-Incaic elements, the image could represent the ancient temple of Pachacamac, built in honor of the local god of the place, popular in much of the northern part of the Inca Empire, although the perspective seems more in line with the much larger and more recent Temple of the Sun built by the Incas.
The local non-Inca temple at Pachacamac was occupied by the Wari (among others), but when the Incas conquered the sactuary it was an Ichma temple and was painted with distinctive Ichma motifs (very diferent from Wari's), so it is also called the Painted Temple. In this temple survived a representation of the god Pachacamac, a wooden pole dating to the Wari period. As I said the Chavin were much older and all their sanctuaries and style had already been abandoned long ago, none surviving into the time of the Incas, not to mention that Chavin stone stelae are extremely rare and the few found are in the heart of Chavin, in its temple and nearby vicinity, not a single one has been found on the coast or so far away.

>>14432567
Knitting didn't exist in the pre-Columbian Andes, although they knew practically all other weaving techniques known today.

Similarly, ponchos appear to have been rare in comparison to today. Although they appear in some pre-Inca cultures (especially coastal ones) such as Paracas, for the most part they did not have the proportions of today's ponchos, the common attire of most highland provinces during the Inca empire was an uncu, which is a sleeveless tunic with a yacolla or blanket around it, which was still the common attire recorded in many parts in early colonial times, the rise in popularity of today's ponchos is rather hazy, but seems to have been an evolution of uncus from which the sides were left unstitched.

The 14th cenetury knight Geoffroi de Charny wrote a guide to knighthood, known simply enough as 'the Book of Chivalry.' While he himself seemed mentally snae, he did raise concern for the long-term toll that warfare could have on other knights. Here's one exerpt where he discusses the various horrors medeival knights would be forced to brave.

>"In this profession one has to endure heat, hunger and hard work, to sleep little and often to keep watch. And to be exhausted and to sleep uncomfortably on the ground only to be abruptly awakened. And you will be powerless to change the situation. You will often be afraid when you see your enemies coming towards you with lowered lances to run you through and with drawn swords to cut you down. Bolts and arrows come at you and you do not know how best to protect yourself. You see people killing each other, fleeing, dying and being taken prisoner and you see the bodies of your dead friends lying before you. But your horse is not dead, and by its vigorous speed you can escape in dishonour. But if you stay, you will win eternal honour. Is he not a great martyr, who puts himself to such work?"

I find it hard to believe Knights did not suffer from psychological trauma as a result of their profession though given the difference in culture and upbringing it probably manifested itself differently from what we see today. Just like how modern soldiers with PTSD have outbursts different from WW1 soldiers suffering from Shell Shock did due to the different conditions that created their trauma in the first place.
I imagine killing enemies up close and personal only to take the spoils from your defeated enemies after a victorious battle as well as the need to raid and pillage from farms and villages just to survive probably caused immense feelings of guilt and shame due to their Christian upbringing. So I'd assume their trauma probably manifested mostly in deeply religious outbursts as well as over indulging in the typical vices such as alcohol, gambling, and sex. When seeking help with their trauma Knights likely turned to the Church instead of peers or loved ones due to social stigmas, and would be "prescribed" a penance by their confessors as their trauma was probably indistinguishable from a guilty conscience. In the worst of cases Knights suffering from trauma probably sought to retire to a monastery hoping the religious lifestyle and escape from their knightly duties would grant them a sense of peace.
Of course as with modern PTSD just because an event caused trauma for one person dosen't mean the person next to them who experienced the same thing will suffer PTSD as well, and medieval ideals such as Chivalry, Faith, and Duty to one's Liege probably served as bulwarks helping many Knights to engage in their profession unaffected or less affected by any psychological trauma.

>>14445832
Warfare from pretty much the entirety of the high and late middle ages in W. Europe had the tendency to be mostly focused around siege action and raiding. Pitched battles are an inherently huge gamble, and they tended to be on the very rare side of things. It's not stupid to say that the majority of warfare of that time was based around sieging, because that technically isn't false (though, raiding and skirmishing should also be included in that).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14447218
>>14447218
Tbf to who you were responding to, death was outright rare for most knights throughout the middle ages; if we consider that warfare of the period and region (particularly W. Europe) oriented mostly around either siege warfare or raiding/skirmish actions (and that pitched battle was generally uncommon), death was not a great risk for pretty much anybody of aristocratic standing. Knights were almost always on horseback and had the greatest ability to flee and also the least reason to be killed rather than captured. The risk of death for them would greatly increase when in a pitched battle, though even then the majority of knights deployed tend to survive (with exceptions, such as in Azincourt).

If we consider this and look at an analysis such as this one: https://acoup.blog/2020/04/16/collections-a-trip-through-bertran-de-born-martial-values-in-the-12th-century-occitan-nobility/

we can really see that contemporary knights really did see warfare as more of a sport (though still grim) and even as enjoyment. There's always a risk of death, but their entire lives (being military, aristocratic men) oriented around warfare, and warfare wasn't foreign to them.

>>14441139
The issue with defaulting to 'energy' as a basic substrate is the unwieldy nature of its primary meaning. What we refer to as 'energy' is but a abstraction representation of the innate capacity of action that a given object possesses, i.e. of something influencing or causing a change in something else in a noticeable, observable, or scientifically measurable way (usually in the form of motion, which is the most basic phenomena of observable). But this definition loses its very coherence when we start talking about quantum fields as vectors of influence overlapping one another in spacetime; the ontology ceases to be about 'things' in the material sense and becomes 'digital' in the sense that discrete units of information become the foundation of reality. The overlapping fields are analogous to layers or subsystems of a complex information processing system that, taken together, produces and interprets the content of reality (i.e. of the cosmos). This is pretty much what theoretical physicists, mathematicians, and software programmers spend all their day doing; establishing frameworks or structures for the interpretation of data, and working out the relationships that exist among quantities and qualities (i.e. variables) and how they interact to produce more complex variables and larger or smaller quantities, depending on the operation/interaction.

Now, as even a child can understand, the meaning of information, whether it is linguistic, numerical, or visual, is dependent on the context in which it is presented. 1+1=2 only insomuch as the addition of identical discrete quantities yields a greater quantity which is itself specified as the sum of its antecedents. What this means is that there are necessary preconditions in any information system in order for there to be data; the interpretative apparatus cannot 'emerge' or 'develop' alongside the data, but rather stands behind it and makes it intelligible. Thus, even an A.I. that can 'learn' in the sense that it can develop functions beyond that of the programmer's initial coding is still limited by the constraints of its interpretive nexus, and, hence, the amount of data it can act upon. There can be no 'new' data apart from the discrete units of information that were already present in the system as a baseline, as well as the varying ways of combining them to form larger structures of meaning, itself a process utterly reliant upon the 'architecture' or interpretative grid of the system.

But where does data (i.e. the content reality) come from in the first place? After all, I mentioned above that there can be no 'new' data in the sense of information introduced by the system itself (i.e the contextual framework of rules for interpreting reality) outside that which it has been initially supplied. Both data and the program which interprets it must themselves be necessarily supplied by an external source, who in everyday software production and maintenance we refer to as the programmer. It is he or she that both writes the program as well as supplies the basic units of code that serve as signals for the conveying of information.

This elaborate example depicts the main thrust of the contingency argument as presented in modern terms.

All this talk about "self-configuring", "self-processing", or "self-determining" reality simply proves what I had suspected early on: namely, that both you and Langan subscribe to a type of Spinozist monism. You assert that the prescriptive principle which organizes information and delimits meaning within reality is identical with the content of reality; the distinction, as you hold it, is a conceptual one rather than an actual one.

The problem with this view is that it conflates the order of being (the ordo essendi) with the order of knowing (the ordo cognoscendi). That is, you deny the logical and temporal priority of that which norms and delimits information as necessarily preceding that which it acts upon, or the modal entity that conveys or communicates information. The source always precedes the derivative; the cause always precedes the effect.

What Langan and his forebears (Liebniz, Fichte, Schelling, Hegel, Schopenhauer, and Bergson) believe is that consciousness and the volition exercised by rational agents is ultimately what is determinative of reality; the cosmos and its contents are self-interpreting closed system. The issue with this is that the irreversibility of numerous physical processes, as well as the degradation of information coherence and structure over time (i.e. entropy), necessarily disproves it. The universe, just like a software program, displays internal evidence of having a cause prior to and external to itself.

Just as mathematicians can alter the semantic and relational framework within which they examine quantities and variables by revising or replacing the terms (whether they be numerical values or operations therein performed as represented by symbols) that delineate meaning, so too can a programmer delimit and alter the possible meanings that data can possess within the context of the information processing system as a whole. Bottom line? Meaning is dependent or contingent upon a semantic network that precedes it

>>14444628
Gödel's incompleteness theorems are two theorems of mathematical logic that are concerned with the limits of provability in formal axiomatic theories. These results, published by Kurt Gödel in 1931, are important both in mathematical logic and in the philosophy of mathematics. The theorems are widely, but not universally, interpreted as showing that Hilbert's program to find a complete and consistent set of axioms for all mathematics is impossible. The first incompleteness theorem states that no consistent system of axioms whose theorems can be listed by an effective procedure is capable of proving all truths about the arithmetic of natural numbers. For any such consistent formal system, there will always be statements about natural numbers that are true, but that are unprovable within the system. The second incompleteness theorem, an extension of the first, shows that the system cannot demonstrate its own consistency.

Let me explain a bit further.

What caused the big bang?
Something. That's what.
Either it was a result of a previous universe that existed that collapsed or there is some other explanation.
It doesn't really matter.
Because whatever that is also has the same question of: what caused that to happen?
And this goes backwards an infinite number of times.
Everything is the result of a prior action.
Nothing can move on its own.
Except for some thing called a First Mover.
That first mover does not obey any logic we can conceive so far.
It doesn't obey any logic we can conceive of conceiving in the future.
It's illogical.
Yet it is also logical to think that something started all of this since we are here right now.
Unless time is a loop with no beginning or end.
But then: where did the loop come from?
From something outside time, and outside all logical notions of cause and effect.
A thing which should exist because here we are, but is utterly inscrutable to our minds.
That's a god.

>>14438987
Determinist or Necessitarian arguments like this one is the reason why most epicureans, both then and now, tended to be privileged types with a source of income not dependent on their low-achieving lifestyle. The possibility of exercising self-restraint or discipline in and of itself disproves this line of reasoning, as rational action directed towards a goal apart from natural (i.e. physical) constraints and incentives demonstrates the existence of desirable ends external to and transcending purely natural ones. It is why men lay down their lives for their country even if they possess no kin who will benefit directly from their sacrifice, and why certain people refuse to take bribes or slander someone even if they have assurances that they won't be caught. It is why the writer, painter, and dramatist forgoes experience of the material things that they depict via their craft; they are seeking the higher fulfillment of the ideal beauty or objective meaning that they hope to communicate.

When such reasoning fails the test of explaining the behavior and thoughts of men, of whom we possess firsthand knowledge and experience (both in regards to ourselves and to others), then how can it ever hope to be valid as regards to the divine, which is fundamentally unknowable and inaccessible to us, apart from that which can be reasonably inferred about it (i.e. its transcendence, eternity, omnipotence, etc) or by its direct disclosure of itself via special revelation? The Stoics, Platonists, and Peripatetics btfo'd this line of reasoning millennia ago, to say nothing of Jewish, Christian, and Muslim critiques.

Hence, this so-called 'problem' is a joke, and is only touted by midwit hedonists and fedorafags online who want to excuse themselves from moral obligations external to their own subjective dictates or whims of fancy. But, by all means, keep spamming the board with this shitty, recycled bait. It keeps the traffic coming and the ad revenue accruing.

Man suffered the penalty of rebelling against God's command, namely the forfeiture of communion with His Creator, who is the source and sustainer of all life. Hence, Adam 'died' in the garden in that he severed his 'life-line' with the eternal God; spiritually, his death was immediate, while physically, the sentence ran its course like a disease until the man finally returned to the dust from whence he came.

Both the sentence of condemnation (i.e. the guilt) as well as the innate predisposition towards lawlessness (i.e. iniquity or corruption) were inherited and transmitted by Adam's posterity, bringing the entire human race under the power of sin and death. The fact that all men die is testimony to the transgression of our first parents.

Likewise, God cursed the creation as a result of man's disobedience, introducing the resulting physical degradation and principles such as entropy into the Created order.

The consequences of original sin are indeed grave and dire. Thanks, then, be to God who has redeemed us from the power of sin and death through the atoning sacrifice of the Lord Jesus Christ, who became a curse for us so that we might have life in Him. Amen.

>First, Matthew reported the lineage of Christ only back to Abraham; Luke traced it all the way back to Adam. Second, Matthew used the expression “begat;” Luke used the expression “son of,” which results in his list being a complete reversal of Matthew’s. Third, the two genealogical lines parallel each other from Abraham to David. Fourth, beginning with David, Matthew traced the paternal line of descent through Solomon; Luke traced the maternal line through Solomon’s brother, Nathan.
>A fifth factor that must be recognized is that the two lines (paternal and maternal) link together in the intermarriage of Shealtiel and Zerubbabel. But the linkage separates again in the two sons of Zerubbabel—Rhesa and Abiud. Sixth, the two lines come together once again for a final time in the marriage of Joseph and Mary. Joseph was the end of the paternal line, while Mary was the last of the maternal line as the daughter of Heli.
>The reason Joseph is said to be the “son” of Heli (Mary’s father) brings forth a seventh consideration: the Jewish use of “son.” Hebrews used the word in at least five distinct senses: (1) in the sense used today of a one-generation offspring; (2) in the sense of a descendant, whether a grandson or a more remote descendant many generations previous, e.g., Matthew 1:1; 21:9; 22:42 (“begat” had this same flexibility in application); (3) as a son-in-law (the Jews had no word to express this concept and so just used “son”—e.g., 1 Samuel 24:16; 26:17); (4) in accordance with the Levirate marriage law (Deuteronomy 25:5-10; cf. Matthew 22:24-26), a deceased man would have a son through a surrogate father who legally married the deceased man’s widow (e.g., Ruth 2:20; 3:9,12; 4:3-5); and (5) in the sense of a step-son who took on the legal status of his step-father—the relationship sustained by Jesus to Joseph (Matthew 13:55; Mark 6:3; Luke 3:23; 4:22; John 6:42).
part1/2

So recent genetic evidence shows Iranians have little to do with the Ancient Persian invaders from Central Asia, who most closely resembled Yaghnobis or Tajiks. However, evidence shows Iranians are not that mixed either! The Dinkha Tepe BIA B samples show all Iranians cluster near Kassites, Hurrians, and/or Gutians, who can be collectively referred as "Zagrosians". I believe Dinkha Tepe BIA B was most likely Kassite, so Iranians are in a sense descendants of Kassites. Kassites seem impressive, but their cultural legacy was lost. They ruled Babylon for ~500 years.

The Lurs and Bakhtiaris are, in this sense, the purest Iranians based on this standard, and most Iranians cluster near them. However, they have negligible Aryan admixture, just like most Iranians.

This means Iranian identity is based on a LARP. The Aryan+BMAC invaders were no different than Arabs and Turks in this respect then, and none of them left a major genetic impact.

Should Iran reinvent its national identity? Given that Kassites were neither IE nor Semitic speakers, is it likely they closely resembled the Sumerians?

I think Iranians should seriously consider what their identity is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Steve Oken became one of five people executed by the state of Maryland in the modern era of capital punishment for three sadistic murders of women in the fall of 1987. Born in 1962, he was adopted shortly after his birth by a Jewish couple, David and Davida Oken, of Randallstown, Maryland. David Oken worked as a pharmacist and the family was comfortably middle class. Steve grew up alongside the Okens' natural-born son and daughter, both of whom went on to successful careers in the medical field. The family were not strictly observant Jews, but they did sometimes attend services at Baltimore Hebrew Congregation where Steve had his bar mitzvah.

For the most part, Steve was a relatively normal child and was active in the various athletics programs at Randallstown High School. He attended health sciences classes at the University of Maryland but dropped out before he could qualify for a degree. Steve also assisted in running the family pharmacy across the street from Johns Hopkins Hospital. However, Davida Oken remembered that when Steve was about 11, she had told him he was adopted. "He didn't want to believe it at first and then screamed for two hours."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Steve met a girl named Phyllis Hirt while working at the pharmacy and they got married after a few weeks of dating. It was in 1986, not long after his 24th birthday, that something started to change. He began skipping work more frequently and abusing drugs (both illicit and drugs pilfered from the pharmacy) and alcohol. David and Davida confronted their son and told him he'd better shape up if he wanted to continue at the pharmacy. He underwent on and off psychotherapy for about a year, and then on October 13, 1987, he was arrested on assault charges after getting into a physical confrontation with a hotel clerk in Baltimore. A week after that, he beat up a prostitute in a parking lot at Baltimore Harbor after she insisted on being paid up front for her services.

On November 1, while Phyllis Oken was on a business trip in distant California, Steve posed alternately as a stranded motorist and a doctor as he sought entrance to apartments in White Marsh.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The next morning, Keith Garvin, a US Navy serviceman, reported for duty at the Navy base in Oceana, Virginia. Garvin had gotten a pass to visit his young wife Dawn Marie in their White Marsh apartment over the weekend--the couple had not been married very long and he was now returning to the base. Upon arriving, Keith called Dawn on the phone to let her know where he was, but there was no answer at the apartment. He tried a couple of times and still got no response. Getting concerned, Keith called his father-in-law Frederick Romano and told him he should check on Dawn. Frederick called the apartment twice and no one answered the phone.

At this point, Frederick decided he'd better go there in person and see what was up. As he arrived at the door of Dawn's apartment, he knew something was very wrong here. The door was partially open and all the lights and the TV were on. It didn't take long for Frederick to walk into horror. His pretty red-haired daughter lay nude and motionless on the bed. A glass bottle was pushed into her vagina. Numb with shock, Frederick tried to perform CPR before noticing blood trickling from her forehead. He dialed 911. Paramedics arrived but it was obvious that Dawn was beyond help and she was pronounced dead at 11:43 AM.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Later that evening, the Baltimore homicide unit arrived to analyze the crime scene. The apartment had no signs of forced entry. Dawn's clothing was scattered on the floor near the bed and it appeared that her bra had been torn off of her. The detectives also noticed a small piece of rubber on the floor near the TV set. In the bedroom, he found two spent .25 caliber shell casings on the bed, one of which was lying on top of a shirt. The shirt was bloodstained and had what was believed to be a bullet hole in it. An autopsy revealed that Dawn had died of two close contact gunshot wounds to the head--one behind the right ear and another above the left eye.

On November 9, Steve Oken appeared in court to face charges for the assault on the hotel clerk a month earlier. A judge gave him probation and ordered him to attend Al Anon meetings. Five days later, he was arrested on DUI charges. The day after that, his sister-in-law Patricia Hirt, 43 and an administrative secretary at Johns Hopkins Hospital, was visiting his White Marsh townhouse to return a camera she'd borrowed. Several hours later, her sister Danielle expressed concern that she'd gone missing and some bad could have happened to her.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On the morning of November 16, Sgt. Sid Branham of the BCPD received a call concerning a possible missing person. Along with Lt. Dave Harvey, he entered Steve Oken's apartment to find no one inside, but the door was ajar and there were bloodstains on the floor and in a variety of other places, as well as a heap of women's clothing. Branham left Harvey to watch the apartment while the BCPD obtained a search warrant. The next morning, Charles Naylor, a BCPD homicide detective, received a call that a dead woman had been found off I-95 and White Marsh Boulevard. The body was taken in for processing, and within an hour identified as Patricia Hirt.

It didn't take long to suspect Steve Oken, not in the least because the murder took place inside his apartment, was extremely similiar to Dawn Garvin's murder, and the fact that Steve himself was nowhere to be seen. He had taken his sister-in-law's white '79 Mustang and fled the area. In fact, as police were discovering his bloodied apartment, he was 400 miles away in Kittery, Maine, just on the east side of the New Hampshire border.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This quaint seaside New England town, home to about 9,300 people in the 1980s, is home to the Portsmouth Naval Yard which is the town's largest employer. Steve Oken knew the area well from childhood vacations in New England. On the afternoon of November 16, he checked into the Coachman Motor Inn. He told the hotel manager, Diana Ott, that he wanted a room for one night, signed the registration papers, and paid with a Visa card. She gave Oken the keys to Room 48, and he dutifully went off there. Ms. ott then realized that Oken had left his credit card on the desk, and she called his room to let him know. Ott's shift ended a short time later and she told her replacement, Lori Ward, that one of the hotel boarders had left his credit card on the reception desk and to make sure he got it back.

At 6:00 PM, Ott called the registration desk to check on Ward but got no answer. She called the hotel maintenance man who gave her shocking news that Ward had been found murdered. Ott rushed back to the hotel in a panic.

While this was going on, Steve was in Freeport, 60 miles to the north of Kittery and had never actually checked out of the Coachman. He checked into the Freeport Inn and paid in cash for one night's lodging in Room 250. The clerk, Kathy Jones, remarked with surprise that Steve had a visible bloodstain on the back of his head. He told her he was fine and it was nothing to worry about. Steve emerged from his room the morning of the 17th and paid for an additional night's lodgings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Back at the Coachman, Lori Ward's body had been found in a back room behind the front reception desk. The 25 year old hotel clerk was dead of a single gunshot wound to the head and had been beaten and raped. The cash register had been pilfered of $300. Police knocked on all rooms in the hotel and found that Room 48 was empty and there was no sign of Steve Oken or his car anywhere. The hotel staff replied that four rooms were current vacant. In Room 48, the cops found a vodka bottle, a half gallon jug of orange juice, socks, bits of rope, a bloodied shirt, and blood stains on the wall. There was no luggage anywhere and no sign that the room had been used; the bed wasn't even down.

Diane Ott provided Steve's registration info for his car, a white '79 Mustang with Maryland plates. Police scanned the plate number and learned that the car was stolen and that its occupant was wanted on suspicion of two murders in Maryland. Steve Oken was arrested at the Freeport Inn for first degree murder.

Tried in Maine for the murder of Lori Ward, he was found guilty and sentenced to life in prison with no possibility of parole. It didn't end there, of course, because he would also be extradicted to Maryland to stand trial for the two other murders, and unlike Maine, the Old Line State had capital punishment. The evidence that he had killed Patricia Hirt and Dawn Garvin was overwhelming--a .22 pistol found in his apartment was matched through ballistics tests to the rounds found in the victims' bodies, and an imprint matching his shoes found in Garvin's apartment. Witnesses had seen him stalking the apartment complex and trying to gain entry to different apartments. Steve Oken was sentenced to death.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Furthermore, Steve had confessed to a psychiatrist about murdering Dawn Garvin. On November 1, he encountered the 20 year old Army clerk outside her apartment and asked if he could use her phone. Since he was an apparently normal-seeming young man close to her age, she readily let him inside. Once in, Steve slammed the door shut, pulled out his .22 pistol, and ordered Dawn to undress. He told her to masturbate herself. As she complied, he masturbated along with her. Steve then demanded she perform oral sex on him. He next tried to have intercourse with Dawn in several different positions, even attempting anal sex, but was unable to achieve an erection. He then grabbed a bottle of Durkee's hot sauce from the kitchen table and ordered Dawn to masturbate with it. He tried once again to masturbate himself, was still unable to get an erection, and finally snapped and fired two gunshots into her head.

Nobody knows why exactly he did it, and he appeared to not know himself. Childhood friends, classmates, and schoolteachers said he had been pretty much normal and well-adjusted as far as anyone could tell. He did well in school and had no obvious warning signs that a budding psychopathic killer was in the making.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Steve granted an interview to the Baltimore Jewish Times in 2001. He said that his life had been spiraling into a vortex of substance abuse, depression, and arguments with his wife Phyllis (who divorced him shortly after his arrest). There was no one cause for the murders, and he said he felt terrible for all the pain and suffering he caused his victims and their families. He indicated that he had become more religious since entering prison and had taken to carrying "tellifin", small boxes containing scraps of paper with Torah verses written on them.

He was one of eleven persons and the only Jew on Maryland's death row. This made him unusual in of itself--American Jews have an extremely low rate of violent crime. Sure, there'd been serial killer Harvey Glatman who murdered several young women in Los Angeles in the 1950s and met his fate in California's gas chamber, but as Rabbi Jacob Max of the Moses Montefiore-Anshe Emunah Hebrew Congregation, who met with the Okens and Steve, remarked "You hear of our people being convicted of white collar crimes, but the idea of a Jew sitting on death row is something the community doesn't know how to handle." He urged the state of Maryland to send Steve to Maine and allow him to serve his life sentence there instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To be completely fair, Steve was not actually an ethnic Jew, he had been born a Gentile and adopted at two days old by David and Davida Oken. However, he was raised in a Jewish home, circumcised, practiced the Jewish religion, and for all practical purposes considered himself Jewish. The fact that he knew he was adopted and did not know his real parents was long a source of torment to him; he had wanted badly to track down his birth mother, but she had disappeared to parts unknown.

Steve's crimes also proved hard on the Okens as they held a lot of sway in the local Jewish community and were now seen as pariahs. "I had people saying to me 'What is wrong with you? Why didn't you raise your son better?'", said Davida. The community snubbed the Okens and offered little comfort or moral support to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Lou Jacobs of Jewish Big Brother/Sister agreed that the community snubbing the Okens was "sad but typical in this kind of situation" and added that Jews held as wide a range of opinions on capital punishment as the rest of America. He sent a form letter to more than 40 area rabbis to inform them about Oken's situation, and to suggest using the case as a means of creating dialogue about capital punishment in their congregations. He got only a few replies, one from an offended rabbi who said he only opened a conversation about the death penalty because a Jewish man was on death row. Jacobs said that the Okens deserved more moral support from the community and to not be seen as pariahs. He added that Jews have a difficult time with self-criticism or acknowledging mistakes due to their history as a persecuted/marginalized group. "I don't think we have a problem with substance abuse or domestic violence in our community. I think we're pretty immune to it due to our conditioning. But the fact is, a Jewish man is on death row in the state of Maryland and could be executed at any time."

Arthur C. Abramson, executive director of the Baltimore Jewish Council however said Steve Oken was simply a brutal murderer and rapist, and his being Jewish had nothing to do with it.

Davida Oken talked to her son on the phone and visited him in prison regularly, but avoided discussing the murders. "I saw no reason to do so, nor did I think I would learn anything useful from talking about it." The Okens lobbied and protested almost to the end against their son's execution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In 2002, Maryland governor Parris Glendening put a moratorium on capital punishment, claiming it was unfair and racially biased, since the murder of a white victim was significantly more likely to result in a jury requesting the death penalty than the murder of a non-white victim. He pointed out that every individual on Maryland's death row was convicted of murdering a white person. His successor Robert Erlich lifted the moratorium which paved the way for Steve Oken's execution via lethal injection on the morning of June 17, 2004. His remains were cremated and scattered.
